ğŸ¬ I saw â€œThor: Ragnarokâ€ today and thoroughly enjoyed it. The â€œThorâ€ and â€œCaptain Americaâ€ series started off a little weak but ended up much stronger than the â€œIron Manâ€ series, which had the opposite trajectory. Itâ€™s upsetting that they never made a â€œBlack Widowâ€ movie series.

Another SwiftoDo update will come at the end of next week, as long as I can get the timing right with App Store review. I cannot promise weekly updates forever, but right now I am trying to release the best version possible to my users, as soon as possible.

SwiftoDo 2.8.0 is now available in the App Store. It adds a picker to make adding recurrence pattern tags (for daily, weekly, monthly, etc.) to tasks easier. It also lets you drop tasks onto the task list from other apps (iPad only).

I am listening to music from my MacBook Pro today, via the Oppo HA-2SE. One benefit is that it charges through its micro USB input, so playtime is unlimited. iTunes is slower and buggier than the iOS Music app, though.

Adding my Nest thermostat to HomeKit via HomeBridge has made my life a little better. I do have a suggestion for Apple, though: â€œHey Siri, set thermostat to 70Âº F and let no one in my family change it, ever, for any reason.â€ Maybe I donâ€™t need a smart thermostat after all.

I downloaded Visual Studio Code on my Windows work machine today. I donâ€™t see how it will be better than Sublime Text for me however. I mostly need speed and some extensibility, and donâ€™t need to compile or debug so much.

Tonight I set up HomeBridge on an otherwise unused Raspberry Pi to control my Nest thermostat via Siri and HomeKit. The hardest part for me was getting it set up as a service, because I hadnâ€™t used systemd before. I blame/thank FreeBSD for that!
If Apple really is slowing down and fixing bugs, rather than adding features, I wish they would work more on Xcode 9, which is still a mess for me for Swift development.
